Award.AwardTitle: CANSec: The Central Area Networking and Security Workshop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of CanSec (formerly Greater Kansas Area Security Workshop or KanSec) is to provide a regular forum for researchers and students across several Midwestern states (Kansas, Missouri, Colorado, Iowa, Arkansas, Oklahoma, Nebraska, Texas, and Indiana) to present research and educational activities, and to promote interactions and collaborations. The workshop was initiated by three NSA/DHS National Centers of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Education (CAE/IAE) and IA Research (CAE/R) in the State of Kansas: the University of Kansas, the Kansas State University, and the Fort Hays State University. In 2013 and 2014, they met as KanSec; in 2015, they have renamed the conference CanSec, and broadened the scope to other Midwestern states.

This grant provides support of students to attend CanSec, where they can interact with peers and faculty from across the region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Kansas received funds from NSF to provide travel awards for students working in the area of cyber security to attend the Central Area Networking and Security (CANSec) Workshop. This NSF travel grant provided travel awards to a total of 82 students attending four CANSec workshops in 2015 - 2017.

Information security is becoming extremely important in today’s society. The CANSec workshop is a semi-annual event that brings together researchers and practitioners in security- and networking-related fields across the central area of the US, including but not limited to the states of Kansas, Missouri, Arkansas, Oklahoma, Colorado, Nebraska, Iowa, etc. The objective of the CANSec workshop is to provide a regular forum for presenting research and education activities in all areas related to computer and communication security, as well as promoting interactions and collaborations among scholars and students and between academia and industry. It offers a variety of sessions including keynote talks, research oral and poster presentations, industrial-academia joint panels, and cyber defense competitions. This provides students a chance to present their ideas and research to other students, faculty, and professionals in a constructive environment, and to learn and practice cyber defense skills in a real-world scenario.

The CANSec workshop promotes the development and collaboration in information security research and education in the Great Plains region with several EPSCoR states including Kansas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Nebraska. The CANSec organizing team strives to keep low costs for the attendees to accommodate more student participants and a broader audience. Students were encouraged to participate in the workshop activities such as oral research project presentations, poster presentations, and cyber defense competitions. The organizing committee of each workshop event selected outstanding students for the NSF travel awards, which covered a part of their travel costs for attending the workshop.
